### Executive Summary
On [Fictional Date], multiple financial organizations reported suspicious network activities, leading to the discovery of the 'ShadowMimic' campaign. This fictional scenario, created for educational purposes, involves a multi-stage attack leveraging social engineering, credential theft, and sophisticated evasion methods. The attack began with the adversary establishing a deceptive Facebook account impersonating a tech support representative to initiate contact with employees. Concurrently, they acquired compromised administrator credentials from an access broker network to gain unauthorized access. Upon infiltration, security scans revealed that the Guest account was accessible with blank password credentials, which the actors exploited to move laterally within the network. The threat actor then executed 'systemctl start backdoor.service' to activate a remote access tool while using raw sockets to craft custom packets that concealed command and control channels. To evade detection, malware executed regasm.exe to register a rogue COM component and utilized encrypted binaries with base64 encoded strings for payload delivery. Further persistence was achieved by modifying HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\EventLog settings to load a malicious DLL instead of the legitimate service. The actors also changed Okta conditional access policies to weaken session timeout requirements using compromised credentials and ran tscon.exe to hijack an established remote desktop connection. For command and control, the malware dynamically registered a new DNS A record pointing to its C2 server and injected C2 traffic into image files like file.jpg to bypass network detection mechanisms. Logs from affected systems showed unusual spikes in network traffic and failed login attempts, but these were initially dismissed as routine anomalies. The organization's background includes a recent merger, leading to inconsistent security policies across departments, which may have contributed to the simulated breach. This report serves as a training tool to highlight the importance of monitoring for these techniques in real-world scenarios.
